body: FYI @mkouba, I created the issue, but this is coming from a Roq user.

Ok but then you can't use `{faClass.trim}` for example or whatever. I really think have a way to do it with variable would be way better..

To go your way, at least we could make it a bit simpler by creating an alias for `{#fragment id=faClass rendered=false}`.
We could name it `{#capture faClass}` ,`register` or `declare`.

We have a couple of options but I'd like to keep the naming consistent. One of the reason is that user tags are _isolated_ by default (cannot reference the data from the parent context) but fragments are not. So we should name those parts "fragments" but make it easier to use.

I think that we should add a fragment namespace resolver so that it's possible to use a fragment in an expression, e.g. `{frg:faClass}`; this would allow thins like `{frg:faClass.strip}` or `{#let preview=frg:faClass.substring(0,10)}`. The downside of this approach is that you can't use additional params. We could try to add something later.

It should be also easier to define a hidden fragment too. `{#fragment id=faClass rendered=false}` can be shortened to `{#fragment faClass rendered=false}` but I think that we can follow the syntax of `{#include}` and add the `_hidden` flag, i.e. `{#fragment faClass _hidden}`. Alternatively, we could add an alias like `hidd_fragment` -> `{#hidd_fragment faClass}`.

That's sounds very good, I would just use `{#capture}` as the name that means `{#fragment hidden=true}`.

Having a shortcut to avoid having to specify the `id` would be great like you suggested `{#capture foo} = {#capture id=foo}`.

For consumption having a namespace is perfect as it solve the coping issue. Let's have `{fragment:foo}` and `{capture:foo}` be  aliases for usage sake:

```html
{#capture faClass}
foo
{/}
bar {capture:faClass}
```

=>

```html
bar foo
```

issue.title: Qute: add fragment named resolvers and capture alias for hidden fragment
